    required
    string
    uid: missionId

    A unique name for this particular run of a survey. The timestamp of when the survey was started is typically included, or the mission ID might contain a user entered value to enable them to uniquely identify the purpose of this survey.

    recordNumber
    required
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: recordNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent record should have its number incremented by 1.

    accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

    heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    sourceAddress
    required
    string

    Source MAC Address, the original source of the frame.

    destinationAddress
    string
    uid: destinationAddress

    Destination MAC Address, the final destination of the frame.

    signalStrength
    number
    format: float[ -200 .. 200 ]uid: signalStrength

    The signal strength of the received signal in dBm.

    txPower
    number
    format: float[ -200 .. 200 ]uid: txPower

    The power in dBm that the device used to transmit the signal.

    technology
    string
    uid: technology

    The Bluetooth wireless technology system that is used in this frame. See the BLUETOOTH SPECIFICATION Version 5.0 | Vol 1, Part A Section 1 (page 166) for more details.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "BR_EDR"
    • "LE"
    supportedTechnologies
    string
    uid: supportedTechnologies

    The Bluetooth wireless technology systems that are supported be the transmitting device. See the BLUETOOTH SPECIFICATION Version 5.0 | Vol 1, Part A Section 1 (page 166) for more details.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "BR_EDR"
    • "LE"
    • "DUAL"
    otaDeviceName
    string
    uid: otaDeviceName

    The Bluetooth device name is the user-friendly name that a Bluetooth device exposes to remote devices. See the BLUETOOTH SPECIFICATION Version 5.0 | Vol 3, Part C Section 3.2.2 (page 1988) for more details.

    channel
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 78 ]

    The channel on which this frame was recorded. See the BLUETOOTH SPECIFICATION Version 5.0 | Vol 2, Part A Section 2 (page 325) for more details.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • object
    uid: gnssRecordPayload
    version
    required
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

    messageType
    required
    string

    The type of message, must be GnssRecord.

    required
    object

    The payload of this message that contains all the message data.

    deviceSerialNumber
    required
    string
    uid: deviceSerialNumber

    The unique identifier for the device that captured this record. This should be consistent and should never change.

    deviceName
    required
    string
    uid: deviceName

    A human readable name assigned to the device that captured this record. This value can change and is typically used as a human friendly display name.

    deviceTime
    required
    string
    format: date-timeuid: deviceTime

    The timestamp of when this message was created in milliseconds formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    latitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: latitude

    The latitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    longitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: longitude

    The longitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    altitude
    number
    format: floatuid: altitude

    The altitude in meters above MSL representing where this survey record was recorded.

    missionId
    required
    string
    uid: missionId

    A unique name for this particular run of a survey. The timestamp of when the survey was started is typically included, or the mission ID might contain a user entered value to enable them to uniquely identify the purpose of this survey.

    recordNumber
    required
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: recordNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent record should have its number incremented by 1.

    groupNumber
    required
    integer
    format: int32>= 1

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent scan should have its number incremented by 1. For simple frequency sweeps, all detections in the same sweep should have the same group number. For cellular surveys, each scan of the serving cell and neighbor cells should have the same group number.

    deviceModel
    string
    uid: deviceModel

    The model number of the device that this message originated from.

    accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

    heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    constellation
    string
    uid: constellation

    The satellite constellation associated with the record.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "GPS"
    • "GLONASS"
    • "GALILEO"
    • "BEIDOU"
    • "SBAS"
    • "QZSS"
    • "IRNSS"
    spaceVehicleId
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: spaceVehicleId

    The identifier for the space vehicle (SV).

    carrierFreqHz
    integer
    format: int64uid: carrierFreqHz

    The carrier frequency utilized by the SV, in Hz.

    clockOffset
    number
    format: doubleuid: clockOffset

    The clock offset calculated by the receiver based on the space-vehicle time contained in a received navigation message, i.e. the time it took for a given navigation message to be sent from a space vehicle to the receiver's antenna, as calculated by the receiver itself.

    usedInSolution
    boolean
    uid: usedInSolution

    Indicates whether this particular satellite data was used as part of the solution. A value of true indicates that the record was used in the solution, a value of false indiicates that the record was not used in the solution.

    undulationM
    number
    format: float[ -150 .. 150 ]uid: undulationM

    The height in meters of the geoid at a given point, relative to a given reference ellipsoid, i.e. the difference in height between the 'real' surface (ignoring topographical features) and a 'modeled' surface given by a reference ellipsoid such as the one defined by WGS84. Valid range, -150.0 to 150.0.

    latitudeStdDevM
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: latitudeStdDevM

    The standard deviation of the latitude measurement in meters, where a higher value indicates a less precise postion lock. For example, a 5m deviaton indicates that, with 68% confidence, the latitude is within 5m of the reported position; with 95% confidence, the latitude is within 10m of the reported position, etc. This relates to the Horizontal Dilution of Precision (HDOP).

    longitudeStdDevM
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: longitudeStdDevM

    The standard deviation of the longitude measurement in meters, where a higher value indicates a less precise position lock. For example, a 5m deviation indicates that, with 68% confidence, the longitude is within 5m of the reported position; with 95% confidence, the longitude is within 10m of the reported position, etc. This relates to the Horizontal Dilution of Precision (HDOP).

    altitudeStdDevM
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: altitudeStdDevM

    The standatd deviation of the altitude measurement in meters, where a higher value indicates a less precise position lock. For example, a 5m deviation indicates that, with 68% confidence, the altitude is within 5m of the reported position; with 95% confidence, the altitude is within 10m of the reported position, etc. This releates to the Vertical Dilution of Poistion (VDOP), and tends to be higher than the Lat/Lon standard deviations due to GNSS satellites being above GNSS receivers.

    agcDb
    number
    format: float[ -50 .. 50 ]uid: agcDb

    Automatic Gain Control, measured in dB. Valid range, -50.0 to 50.0

    cn0DbHz
    number
    format: float[ -100 .. 100 ]uid: cn0DbHz

    The Carrier-to-noise density in dB-Hz, which represents the measured C/N0 for the signal at the antenna inputCarrier to noise density ratio, measured in dB-Hz. Typical range: 10-50 dB-Hz. The range of possible C/N0 values is 0-63 dB-Hz to handle some edge cases.

    hdop
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 50 ]uid: hdop

    Horizontal Dilution of Precision. Valid range, 0.0 to 50.0.

    vdop
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 50 ]uid: vdop

    Vertical Dilution of Precision. Valid range, 0.0 to 50.0.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • object
    uid: energyDetectionPayload
    version
    required
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

    messageType
    required
    string

    The type of message, must be EnergyDetection.

    required
    object

    The payload of this message that contains all the message data.

    deviceSerialNumber
    required
    string
    uid: deviceSerialNumber

    The unique identifier for the device that captured this record. This should be consistent and should never change.

    deviceName
    required
    string
    uid: deviceName

    A human readable name assigned to the device that captured this record. This value can change and is typically used as a human friendly display name.

    deviceTime
    required
    string
    format: date-timeuid: deviceTime

    The timestamp of when this message was created in milliseconds formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    latitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: latitude

    The latitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    longitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: longitude

    The longitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    altitude
    number
    format: floatuid: altitude

    The altitude in meters above MSL representing where this survey record was recorded.

    missionId
    required
    string
    uid: missionId

    A unique name for this particular run of a survey. The timestamp of when the survey was started is typically included, or the mission ID might contain a user entered value to enable them to uniquely identify the purpose of this survey.

    recordNumber
    required
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: recordNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent record should have its number incremented by 1.

    groupNumber
    required
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: groupNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent scan should have its number incremented by 1. For simple frequency sweeps, all detections in the same sweep should have the same group number. For cellular surveys, each scan of the serving cell and neighbor cells should have the same group number.

    accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

    heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    frequencyHz
    required
    integer
    format: int64>= 1uid: frequencyHz

    The frequency, in Hz, that the radio signal was received on.

    bandwidthHz
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: bandwidthHz

    The bandwidth, in Hz, of the received signal.

    signalStrength
    required
    number
    format: float[ -200 .. 200 ]uid: signalStrength

    The signal strength of the received signal in dBm.

    snr
    number
    format: floatuid: snr

    The Signal to Noise Ratio of the received signal to the noise power measured in dB. A ratio higher than 1:1 (greater than 0 dB) indicates more signal than noise.

    timeUp
    string
    format: date-timeuid: timeUp

    The date & time the energy/signal was detected as active. This is formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    durationSec
    number
    format: float> 0uid: durationSec

    The duration of time, in seconds, that the signal was detected as active.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • object
    uid: signalDetectionPayload
    version
    required
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

    messageType
    required
    string

    The type of message, must be SignalDetection.

    required
    object

    The payload of this message that contains all the message data.

    deviceSerialNumber
    required
    string
    uid: deviceSerialNumber

    The unique identifier for the device that captured this record. This should be consistent and should never change.

    deviceName
    required
    string
    uid: deviceName

    A human readable name assigned to the device that captured this record. This value can change and is typically used as a human friendly display name.

    deviceTime
    required
    string
    format: date-timeuid: deviceTime

    The timestamp of when this message was created in milliseconds formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    latitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: latitude

    The latitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    longitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: longitude

    The longitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    altitude
    number
    format: floatuid: altitude

    The altitude in meters above MSL representing where this survey record was recorded.

    missionId
    required
    string
    uid: missionId

    A unique name for this particular run of a survey. The timestamp of when the survey was started is typically included, or the mission ID might contain a user entered value to enable them to uniquely identify the purpose of this survey.

    recordNumber
    required
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: recordNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent record should have its number incremented by 1.

    groupNumber
    required
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: groupNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent scan should have its number incremented by 1. For simple frequency sweeps, all detections in the same sweep should have the same group number. For cellular surveys, each scan of the serving cell and neighbor cells should have the same group number.

    accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

    heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    frequencyHz
    required
    integer
    format: int64>= 1uid: frequencyHz

    The frequency, in Hz, that the radio signal was received on.

    bandwidthHz
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: bandwidthHz

    The bandwidth, in Hz, of the received signal.

    signalStrength
    required
    number
    format: float[ -200 .. 200 ]uid: signalStrength

    The signal strength of the received signal in dBm.

    snr
    number
    format: floatuid: snr

    The Signal to Noise Ratio of the received signal to the noise power measured in dB. A ratio higher than 1:1 (greater than 0 dB) indicates more signal than noise.

    timeUp
    string
    format: date-timeuid: timeUp

    The date & time the energy/signal was detected as active. This is formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    durationSec
    number
    format: float> 0uid: durationSec

    The duration of time, in seconds, that the signal was detected as active.

    modulation
    string
    uid: modulation

    The modulation type found on the received signal. It is appropriate to leave this blank if the modulation of the signal is unknown, but either the modulation or signalName field should be filled out. If neither of them are known then the energyDetection message should be used instead.

    signalName
    string
    uid: signalName

    The modulation type found on the received signal. It is appropriate to leave this blank if the modulation of the signal is unknown, but either the modulation or signalName field should be filled out. If neither of them are known then the energyDetection message should be used instead.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • object
    uid: deviceStatusPayload
    version
    required
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

    messageType
    required
    string

    The type of message, must be DeviceStatus.

    required
    object

    The payload of this message that contains all the message data.

    deviceSerialNumber
    required
    string
    uid: deviceSerialNumber

    The unique identifier for the device that captured this record. This should be consistent and should never change.

    deviceName
    required
    string
    uid: deviceName

    A human readable name assigned to the device that captured this record. This value can change and is typically used as a human friendly display name.

    deviceTime
    required
    string
    format: date-timeuid: deviceTime

    The timestamp of when this message was created in milliseconds formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    latitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: latitude

    The latitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    longitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: longitude

    The longitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    altitude
    number
    format: floatuid: altitude

    The altitude in meters above MSL representing where this survey record was recorded.

    deviceModel
    string
    uid: deviceModel

    The model number of the device that this message originated from.

    accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

    heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    batteryLevelPercent
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 100 ]uid: batteryLevelPercent

    The percentage of battery remaining (if the device has a battery).

    object
    uid: error

    If present, represents that the device is in an error state.

    errorMessage
    required
    string

    A description of the error state that the device is in.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    mdmOverride
    boolean
    uid: mdmOverride

    Indicates if the device currently has the Mobile Device Mangement (MDM) Override option turned on. If true, the user has forced the MDM options off, if false, the user has left the MDM control in place. Added in version 0.9.0.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • object
    uid: phoneStatePayload
    version
    required
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

    messageType
    required
    string

    The type of message, must be PhoneState.

    required
    object

    The payload of this message that contains all the message data.

    deviceSerialNumber
    required
    string
    uid: deviceSerialNumber

    The unique identifier for the device that captured this record. This should be consistent and should never change.

    deviceName
    required
    string
    uid: deviceName

    A human readable name assigned to the device that captured this record. This value can change and is typically used as a human friendly display name.

    deviceTime
    required
    string
    format: date-timeuid: deviceTime

    The timestamp of when this message was created in milliseconds formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    latitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: latitude

    The latitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    longitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: longitude

    The longitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    altitude
    number
    format: floatuid: altitude

    The altitude in meters above MSL representing where this survey record was recorded.

    missionId
    string
    uid: missionId

    A unique name for this particular run of a survey. The timestamp of when the survey was started is typically included, or the mission ID might contain a user entered value to enable them to uniquely identify the purpose of this survey.

    recordNumber
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: recordNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent record should have its number incremented by 1.

    accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

    heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    simState
    string
    uid: simState

    The current state of the SIM card. The values are taken directly from android.telephony.TelephonyManager#SimState and should be kept in sync with those values. Even the order lines up exactly, which makes conversion easier.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "ABSENT"
    • "PIN_REQUIRED"
    • "PUK_REQUIRED"
    • "NETWORK_LOCKED"
    • "READY"
    • "NOT_READY"
    • "PERM_DISABLED"
    • "CARD_IO_ERROR"
    • "CARD_RESTRICTED"
    • "LOADED"
    • "PRESENT"
    simOperator
    string
    uid: simOperator

    The PLMN portion of the SIM's IMSI. This indicates the provider that issued the SIM card. The format is the MCC and MNC concatenated as one string. Can be 5 or 6 digits in length where the MCC is always 3 digits and the MNC is either 2 or 3.

    array<object>
    domain
    string

    The type of network, either Packet Switched (PS) or Circuit Switched (CS).

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "PS"
    • "CS"
    accessNetworkTechnology
    string

    The technology type for this network, for example, UMTS or LTE. These values mirror the Android TelephonyManager Network Type constants.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "GPRS"
    • "EDGE"
    • "UMTS"
    • "CDMA"
    • "EVDO_0"
    • "EVDO_A"
    • "OnexRTT"
    • "HSDPA"
    • "HSUPA"
    • "HSPA"
    • "IDEN"
    • "EVDO_B"
    • "LTE"
    • "EHRPD"
    • "HSPAP"
    • "GSM"
    • "TD_SCDMA"
    • "IWLAN"
    • "LTE_CA"
    • "NR"
    roaming
    boolean

    Boolean indicating if this device is roaming on this network.

    rejectCause
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    If the UE tried to register with this network and was denied, this vlaue indicates the rejection reason. The values are defined in 3GPP TS 24.008 version 16.7.0 page 536 (Reject cause), and 3GPP TS 24.301 version 16.8.0 page 418 (EMM cause).

    oneOf

    The properties defining the cell. The properties are different for each technology so the object type will be different depending on the accessNetworkTechnology. The name of this field will be different for each object. For example, it will be cellIdentityLte for LTE and cellIdentityNr for NR.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityGsm

    Contains the information about a particular GSM cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    lac
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: lac

    Location Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

    ci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: ci

    Cell Identity of the measured cell, valid range 0-65535.

    arfcn
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: arfcn

    Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid values defined in 3GPP TS 45.005 Release 10 Section 2.

    bsic
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 63 ]uid: bsic

    Base Station Identity Code, consists of NCC and BCC, valid range 0-63 (in octal). For example, a BSIC of 38 maps to an NCC of 4 and BCC of 6.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityCdma

    Contains the information about a particular CDMA cell.

    sid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 32767 ]uid: sid

    System Identification Number, 15 bit number that represents the service provider(s) a base station provides service to.

    nid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: nid

    Network Identification Number, 16 bit number that represents the network within a SID.

    bsid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: bsid

    Base Station Identifier. Exclusively identifies a base station under a SID/NID.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityUmts

    Contains the information about a particular UMTS cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    lac
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: lac

    Location Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

    cid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 268435455 ]uid: cid

    The Cell Identity of the measured cell, 28 bits, the RNC-ID is the first 12 bits, and the C-ID is the last 16 bits, valid range 0-268435455. Defined in 3GPP TS 25.331.

    uarfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 13096 ]uid: uarfcn

    UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number (Downlink), valid range 0-13096, defined in 3GPP TS 25.101 and 3GPP TS 25.102.

    psc
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 511 ]uid: psc

    Primary Scrambling Code, valid range 0-511.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityLte

    Contains the information about a particular LTE cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mcc

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mnc

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    tac
    integer
    [ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: tac

    Tracking Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

    eci
    integer
    [ 0 .. 268435455 ]uid: eci

    ECI, the Cell Identity of the measured cell, 28 bits. The Macro eNB ID is the first 20 bits of the Cell Identity and the last 8 bits represent the sector. Valid range 0-268435455.

    earfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 262143 ]uid: earfcn

    Downlink E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid range 0-262143, defined in 3GPP TS 36.331 version 14.2.2 Release 14 page 567.

    pci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 503 ]uid: pci

    Physical Cell Identity, valid range 0-503.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityNr

    Contains the information about a particular NR cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mcc

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mnc

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    tac
    integer
    [ 0 .. 16777215 ]uid: nrTac

    NR Tracking Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0 - 16,777,215 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 643.

    nci
    string
    format: int64[ 0 .. 68719476735 ]uid: nci

    NCI, the Cell Identity of the measured cell, 36 bits. The gNB ID is the first 22-32 bits of the NCI and the remaining bits represent the sector. Valid range 0 - 68,719,476,735 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 370.

    narfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 3279165 ]uid: narfcn

    Downlink NR Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid range 0 - 3,279,165, defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 784.

    pci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 1007 ]uid: nrPci

    NR Physical Cell Identity, valid range 0-1007 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 503.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • object
    uid: wcdmaRrcPayload
    version
    required
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

    messageType
    required
    string

    The type of message, must be WcdmaRrc.

    required
    object

    The payload of this message that contains all the message data.

    deviceSerialNumber
    required
    string
    uid: deviceSerialNumber

    The unique identifier for the device that captured this record. This should be consistent and should never change.

    deviceName
    required
    string
    uid: deviceName

    A human readable name assigned to the device that captured this record. This value can change and is typically used as a human friendly display name.

    deviceTime
    required
    string
    format: date-timeuid: deviceTime

    The timestamp of when this message was created in milliseconds formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

    latitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: latitude

    The latitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    longitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: longitude

    The longitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

    altitude
    number
    format: floatuid: altitude

    The altitude in meters above MSL representing where this survey record was recorded.

    missionId
    required
    string
    uid: missionId

    A unique name for this particular run of a survey. The timestamp of when the survey was started is typically included, or the mission ID might contain a user entered value to enable them to uniquely identify the purpose of this survey.

    accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

    heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    channelType
    required
    string

    The channel type that this message was sent on. The channel type represents the logical channel that the raw cellular message was sent over.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "DL_DCCH"
    • "UL_DCCH"
    • "DL_CCCH"
    • "UL_CCCH"
    • "PCCH"
    • "DL_SHCCH"
    • "UL_SHCCH"
    • "BCCH_FACH"
    • "BCCH_BCH"
    • "MCCH"
    • "MSCH"
    • "HandoverToUTRANCommand"
    • "InterRATHandoverInfo"
    • "SystemInformation_BCH"
    • "System_Information_Container"
    • "UE_RadioAccessCapabilityInfo"
    • "MasterInformationBlock"
    • "SysInfoType1"
    • "SysInfoType2"
    • "SysInfoType3"
    • "SysInfoType4"
    • "SysInfoType5"
    • "SysInfoType5bis"
    • "SysInfoType6"
    • "SysInfoType7"
    • "SysInfoType8"
    • "SysInfoType9"
    • "SysInfoType10"
    • "SysInfoType11"
    • "SysInfoType11bis"
    • "SysInfoType12"
    • "SysInfoType13"
    • "SysInfoType13_1"
    • "SysInfoType13_2"
    • "SysInfoType13_3"
    • "SysInfoType13_4"
    • "SysInfoType14"
    • "SysInfoType15"
    • "SysInfoType15bis"
    • "SysInfoType15_1"
    • "SysInfoType15_1bis"
    • "SysInfoType15_2"
    • "SysInfoType15_2bis"
    • "SysInfoType15_2ter"
    • "SysInfoType15_3"
    • "SysInfoType15_3bis"
    • "SysInfoType15_4"
    • "SysInfoType15_5"
    • "SysInfoType15_6"
    • "SysInfoType15_7"
    • "SysInfoType15_8"
    • "SysInfoType16"
    • "SysInfoType17"
    • "SysInfoType18"
    • "SysInfoType19"
    • "SysInfoType20"
    • "SysInfoType21"
    • "SysInfoType22"
    • "SysInfoTypeSB1"
    • "SysInfoTypeSB2"
    • "ToTargetRNC_Container"
    • "TargetRNC_ToSourceRNC_Container"
    pcapRecord
    required
    string
    format: byteuid: pcapRecord

    The raw cellular message bytes encoded in base64. The bytes in this field are the raw message bytes captured from the Over The Air (OTA) cellular radio frame with the appropriate PCAP headers as the prefix. In other words, the bytes are the same bytes that would show up in a pcap file for a cellular message. The general structure consists of a PCAP record header, PPI header, layer 3 header, layer 4 header, a GSMTAP header, followed by the cellular OTA message. Using this structure means that Wireshark, tshark or any other tool that can read GSMTAP pcap records can easily parse out the contents of this message. For more details see the Network Survey+ Android App Source Code.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • object
    uid: umtsNasPayload
    version
    required
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

    required
    string

    The type of message, must be UmtsNas.

    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

    receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

    • "SDCCH"
    • "SDCCH4"
    • "SDCCH8"
    • "TCH_F"
    • "TCH_H"
    • "PACCH"
    • "CBCH52"
    • "PDCH"
    • "PTCCH"
    • "CBCH51"
    • "VOICE_F"
    • "VOICE_H"
    pcapRecord
    required
    string
    format: byteuid: pcapRecord

    The raw cellular message bytes encoded in base64. The bytes in this field are the raw message bytes captured from the Over The Air (OTA) cellular radio frame with the appropriate PCAP headers as the prefix. In other words, the bytes are the same bytes that would show up in a pcap file for a cellular message. The general structure consists of a PCAP record header, PPI header, layer 3 header, layer 4 header, a GSMTAP header, followed by the cellular OTA message. Using this structure means that Wireshark, tshark or any other tool that can read GSMTAP pcap records can easily parse out the contents of this message. For more details see the Network Survey+ Android App Source Code.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • version
    string
    uid: version

    The version number of the Network Survey Messaging API that this message is based off of.

  • messageType
    string
    uid: messageType

    The type of this message. This value must match the message name or the message will not be interpreted correctly.

  • deviceSerialNumber
    string
    uid: deviceSerialNumber

    The unique identifier for the device that captured this record. This should be consistent and should never change.

  • deviceName
    string
    uid: deviceName

    A human readable name assigned to the device that captured this record. This value can change and is typically used as a human friendly display name.

  • deviceTime
    string
    format: date-timeuid: deviceTime

    The timestamp of when this message was created in milliseconds formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

  • latitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: latitude

    The latitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

  • longitude
    number
    format: doubleuid: longitude

    The longitude representing where this survey record was recorded.

  • altitude
    number
    format: floatuid: altitude

    The altitude in meters above MSL representing where this survey record was recorded.

  • missionId
    string
    uid: missionId

    A unique name for this particular run of a survey. The timestamp of when the survey was started is typically included, or the mission ID might contain a user entered value to enable them to uniquely identify the purpose of this survey.

  • recordNumber
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: recordNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent record should have its number incremented by 1.

  • groupNumber
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: groupNumber

    Starts at 1 and each subsequent scan should have its number incremented by 1. For simple frequency sweeps, all detections in the same sweep should have the same group number. For cellular surveys, each scan of the serving cell and neighbor cells should have the same group number.

  • signalStrength
    number
    format: float[ -200 .. 200 ]uid: signalStrength

    The signal strength of the received signal in dBm.

  • deviceModel
    string
    uid: deviceModel

    The model number of the device that this message originated from.

  • accuracy
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: accuracy

    The estimated horizontal accuracy of the provided location, radial, in meters. We define horizontal accuracy as the radius of 68% confidence. In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. A value of 0 indicates there was no available horizontal accuracy.

  • heading
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: heading

    Heading of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from true north. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

  • pitch
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: pitch

    Pitch of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

  • roll
    number
    format: float[ -180 .. 180 ]uid: roll

    Roll of the sensor/antenna, in degrees from the ground plane. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

  • fieldOfView
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 360 ]uid: fieldOfView

    The horizontal field of view of the sensor/antenna in degrees. If absent, then this assumes that the sensor has a 360 degree field of view (i.e. omnidirectional antenna). One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldofView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position.

  • receiverSensitivity
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: receiverSensitivity

    The minimum signal strength that a receiver can detect, in units of dBm. One can use sensor orientation (heading, pitch, roll) and sensor characterisics (fieldOfView, receiverSensitivity) to form more accurate estimates of the transmitter's position or distance from the sensor.

  • provider
    string
    uid: provider

    The company providing the cellular service.

  • mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mcc

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

  • mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mnc

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

  • servingCell
    boolean
    uid: servingCell

    Boolean indicating if this record represents a serving cell record, or a neighbor cell record. If the field is unset then it is unknown if this record is for the serving cell or a neighbor cell. A value of true indicates that the record represents a serving cell, a value of false indicates a neighbor record.

  • lac
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: lac

    Location Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

  • ci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: ci

    Cell Identity of the measured cell, valid range 0-65535.

  • arfcn
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: arfcn

    Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid values defined in 3GPP TS 45.005 Release 10 Section 2.

  • bsic
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 63 ]uid: bsic

    Base Station Identity Code, consists of NCC and BCC, valid range 0-63 (in octal). For example, a BSIC of 38 maps to an NCC of 4 and BCC of 6.

  • ta
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 63 ]uid: ta

    Timing Advance, corresponding to the timing offset a mobile phone needs to use when transmitting a signal to the tower.

  • sid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 32767 ]uid: sid

    System Identification Number, 15 bit number that represents the service provider(s) a base station provides service to.

  • nid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: nid

    Network Identification Number, 16 bit number that represents the network within a SID.

  • zone
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: zone

    A collection of one or more base stations treated as a unit when determining whether a mobile station should perform zone-based registration.

  • bsid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: bsid

    Base Station Identifier. Exclusively identifies a base station under a SID/NID.

  • channel
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: channel

    Channel number that corresponds to a frequency.

  • pnOffset
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 511 ]uid: pnOffset

    Pseudo Random Noise, 0-511, used to differentiate sectors on base stations.

  • ecio
    number
    format: floatuid: ecio

    Measure of the quality / cleanliness of the signal from the tower to the modem (signal to noise). Energy per chip to Interference power ratio measured in dB.

  • cid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 268435455 ]uid: cid

    The Cell Identity of the measured cell, 28 bits, the RNC-ID is the first 12 bits, and the C-ID is the last 16 bits, valid range 0-268435455. Defined in 3GPP TS 25.331.

  • uarfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 13096 ]uid: uarfcn

    UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number (Downlink), valid range 0-13096, defined in 3GPP TS 25.101 and 3GPP TS 25.102.

  • psc
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 511 ]uid: psc

    Primary Scrambling Code, valid range 0-511.

  • rscp
    number
    format: floatuid: rscp

    Reference Signal Code Power in dBm.

  • ecno
    number
    format: floatuid: ecno

    Received energy per chip divided by the power density in the band in dB. The value is negative as the RSCP is smaller than the total received power. Added in version 0.8.0.

  • tac
    integer
    [ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: tac

    Tracking Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

  • eci
    integer
    [ 0 .. 268435455 ]uid: eci

    ECI, the Cell Identity of the measured cell, 28 bits. The Macro eNB ID is the first 20 bits of the Cell Identity and the last 8 bits represent the sector. Valid range 0-268435455.

  • earfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 262143 ]uid: earfcn

    Downlink E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid range 0-262143, defined in 3GPP TS 36.331 version 14.2.2 Release 14 page 567.

  • pci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 503 ]uid: pci

    Physical Cell Identity, valid range 0-503.

  • rsrp
    number
    format: float[ -140 .. -44 ]uid: rsrp

    Reference Signal Received Power in dBm, valid range -44 to -140, corresponding to RSRP_97 to RSRP_00 respectively.

  • rsrq
    number
    format: float[ -19.5 .. -3 ]uid: rsrq

    Reference Signal Received Quality in dB, valid range -3 to -19.5, corresponding to RSRQ_34 to RSRQ_00 respectively.

  • lteBandwidth
    string
    uid: lteBandwidth

    The LTE downlink bandwidth in MHz (one of 1.4, 3, 5, 10, 15, 20).

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "MHZ_1_4"
    • "MHZ_3"
    • "MHZ_5"
    • "MHZ_10"
    • "MHZ_15"
    • "MHZ_20"
  • nrTac
    integer
    [ 0 .. 16777215 ]uid: nrTac

    NR Tracking Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0 - 16,777,215 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 643.

  • nci
    string
    format: int64[ 0 .. 68719476735 ]uid: nci

    NCI, the Cell Identity of the measured cell, 36 bits. The gNB ID is the first 22-32 bits of the NCI and the remaining bits represent the sector. Valid range 0 - 68,719,476,735 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 370.

  • narfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 3279165 ]uid: narfcn

    Downlink NR Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid range 0 - 3,279,165, defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 784.

  • nrPci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 1007 ]uid: nrPci

    NR Physical Cell Identity, valid range 0-1007 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 503.

  • ssRsrp
    number
    format: float[ -156 .. -31 ]uid: ssRsrp

    Secondary Synchronization signal Reference Signal Received Power in dBm, valid range -156 to -31, corresponding to RSRP_1 to RSRP_126 respectively as defined in 3GPP TS 38.133 version 16.5.0 Release 16 Table 10.1.6.1-1.

  • ssRsrq
    number
    format: float[ -43 .. 20 ]uid: ssRsrq

    Secondary Synchronization signal Reference Signal Received Quality in dB, valid range -43 to 20, corresponding to SS-RSRQ_1 to SS-RSRQ_127 respectively (increments of 0.5) as defined in 3GPP TS 38.133 version 16.5.0 Release 16 Table 10.1.11.1-1.

  • ssSinr
    number
    format: float[ -23 .. 40 ]uid: ssSinr

    Secondary Synchronization signal signal-to-noise and interference ratio in dB. The reporting range of SS-SINR is defined from -23 dB to 40 dB with 0.5 dB resolution, corresponding to SINR_1 to SINR_127 respectively as defined in 3GPP TS 38.133 version 16.5.0 Release 16 Table 10.1.16.1-1.

  • csiRsrp
    number
    format: float[ -140 .. -44 ]uid: csiRsrp

    Channel State Information (CSI) Reference Signal Received Power in dBm, valid range -140 to -44, corresponding to RSRP_17 to RSRP_113 respectively as defined in 3GPP TS 38.133 version 16.5.0 Release 16 Table 10.1.6.1-1.

  • csiRsrq
    number
    format: floatuid: csiRsrq

    CSI Reference Signal Received Quality in dB.

  • csiSinr
    number
    format: float[ -23 .. 40 ]uid: csiSinr

    CSI signal-to-noise and interference ratio in dB. The reporting range of CSI-SINR is defined from -23 dB to 40 dB with 0.5 dB resolution, corresponding to SINR_1 to SINR_127 respectively as defined in 3GPP TS 38.133 version 16.5.0 Release 16 Table 10.1.16.1-1.

  • sourceAddress
    string
    uid: sourceAddress

    Source MAC Address, the original source of the frame.

  • destinationAddress
    string
    uid: destinationAddress

    Destination MAC Address, the final destination of the frame.

  • bssid
    string
    uid: bssid

    Basic Service Set Identifier, the MAC Address of the Access Point.

  • beaconInterval
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: beaconInterval

    Beacon Interval, in milliseconds. The rate at which beacon frames are sent from an Access Point advertising the existence of the AP.

  • serviceSetType
    string
    uid: serviceSetType

    The Service Set Type that this node belongs to.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "BSS"
    • "ESS"
    • "BSS_ESS"
    • "IBSS"
    • "MBSS"
  • ssid
    string
    uid: ssid

    The Service Set Identifier (aka the Wi-Fi network name), UTF-8 Encoded.

  • supportedRates
    string
    uid: supportedRates

    A list of data rates supported by this device separated by semicolons.

  • extendedSupportedRates
    string
    uid: extendedSupportedRates

    An extended list of data rates supported by this device separated by semicolons.

  • array<string>
    uid: cipherSuites

    A list of the supported cipher suites. See IEEE Std 802.11-2012 Section 8.4.2.27.2 for more details on the 802.11 Cipher Suites.

    Items:
    string
      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "WEP_40"
    • "TKIP"
    • "CCMP"
    • "WEP_104"
    • "GCMP_128"
    • "GCMP_256"
    • "CCMP_256"
    • "BIP_GMAC_128"
    • "BIP_GMAC_256"
    • "BIP_CMAC_256"
    • "OPEN"
    • "WEP"
  • array<string>
    uid: akmSuites

    A list of the supported Authentication and Key Management (AKM) suites. See IEEE Std 802.11-2012 Section 8.4.2.27.3 for more details on the 802.11 AKM Suites.

    Items:
    string
      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "IEEE_8021X"
    • "FT_IEEE_8021X"
    • "IEEE_8021X_SHA256"
    • "PSK"
    • "FT_PSK"
    • "PSK_SHA256"
    • "SAE"
    • "FT_SAE"
    • "TDLS"
    • "OPEN"
  • encryptionType
    string
    uid: encryptionType

    The encryption type used by the Access Point. This field should be kept in sync with the cipherSuites field as it is directly related.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "OPEN"
    • "WEP"
    • "WPA"
    • "WPA_WPA2"
    • "WPA2"
    • "WPA3"
  • wps
    boolean
    uid: wps

    Boolean indicating if this record represents a serving cell record, or a neighbor cell record. If the field is unset then it is unknown if this record is for the serving cell or a neighbor cell. A value of true indicates that the record represents a serving cell, a value of false indicates a neighbor record.

  • nodeType
    string
    uid: nodeType

    The type of station that sent this frame.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "AP"
    • "NON_AP_STA"
    • "STA"
  • standard
    string
    uid: standard

    The 802.11 standard being employed by the device.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "IEEE80211"
    • "IEEE80211A"
    • "IEEE80211B"
    • "IEEE80211G"
    • "IEEE80211BG"
    • "IEEE80211N"
    • "IEEE80211AC"
    • "IEEE80211AX"
  • reason
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: reason

    Clients may disassociate prior to powering off. APs may disassociate clients for various reasons including failure to properly authenticate, for load balancing or timeout reasons, entering a state of maintenance, etc. The 802.11-2016 standard includes a list of disassociation reasons.

  • txPower
    number
    format: float[ -200 .. 200 ]uid: txPower

    The power in dBm that the device used to transmit the signal.

  • technology
    string
    uid: technology

    The Bluetooth wireless technology system that is used in this frame. See the BLUETOOTH SPECIFICATION Version 5.0 | Vol 1, Part A Section 1 (page 166) for more details.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "BR_EDR"
    • "LE"
  • supportedTechnologies
    string
    uid: supportedTechnologies

    The Bluetooth wireless technology systems that are supported be the transmitting device. See the BLUETOOTH SPECIFICATION Version 5.0 | Vol 1, Part A Section 1 (page 166) for more details.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "BR_EDR"
    • "LE"
    • "DUAL"
  • otaDeviceName
    string
    uid: otaDeviceName

    The Bluetooth device name is the user-friendly name that a Bluetooth device exposes to remote devices. See the BLUETOOTH SPECIFICATION Version 5.0 | Vol 3, Part C Section 3.2.2 (page 1988) for more details.

  • constellation
    string
    uid: constellation

    The satellite constellation associated with the record.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "GPS"
    • "GLONASS"
    • "GALILEO"
    • "BEIDOU"
    • "SBAS"
    • "QZSS"
    • "IRNSS"
  • spaceVehicleId
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: spaceVehicleId

    The identifier for the space vehicle (SV).

  • carrierFreqHz
    integer
    format: int64uid: carrierFreqHz

    The carrier frequency utilized by the SV, in Hz.

  • clockOffset
    number
    format: doubleuid: clockOffset

    The clock offset calculated by the receiver based on the space-vehicle time contained in a received navigation message, i.e. the time it took for a given navigation message to be sent from a space vehicle to the receiver's antenna, as calculated by the receiver itself.

  • usedInSolution
    boolean
    uid: usedInSolution

    Indicates whether this particular satellite data was used as part of the solution. A value of true indicates that the record was used in the solution, a value of false indiicates that the record was not used in the solution.

  • undulationM
    number
    format: float[ -150 .. 150 ]uid: undulationM

    The height in meters of the geoid at a given point, relative to a given reference ellipsoid, i.e. the difference in height between the 'real' surface (ignoring topographical features) and a 'modeled' surface given by a reference ellipsoid such as the one defined by WGS84. Valid range, -150.0 to 150.0.

  • latitudeStdDevM
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: latitudeStdDevM

    The standard deviation of the latitude measurement in meters, where a higher value indicates a less precise postion lock. For example, a 5m deviaton indicates that, with 68% confidence, the latitude is within 5m of the reported position; with 95% confidence, the latitude is within 10m of the reported position, etc. This relates to the Horizontal Dilution of Precision (HDOP).

  • longitudeStdDevM
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: longitudeStdDevM

    The standard deviation of the longitude measurement in meters, where a higher value indicates a less precise position lock. For example, a 5m deviation indicates that, with 68% confidence, the longitude is within 5m of the reported position; with 95% confidence, the longitude is within 10m of the reported position, etc. This relates to the Horizontal Dilution of Precision (HDOP).

  • altitudeStdDevM
    number
    format: float>= 0uid: altitudeStdDevM

    The standatd deviation of the altitude measurement in meters, where a higher value indicates a less precise position lock. For example, a 5m deviation indicates that, with 68% confidence, the altitude is within 5m of the reported position; with 95% confidence, the altitude is within 10m of the reported position, etc. This releates to the Vertical Dilution of Poistion (VDOP), and tends to be higher than the Lat/Lon standard deviations due to GNSS satellites being above GNSS receivers.

  • agcDb
    number
    format: float[ -50 .. 50 ]uid: agcDb

    Automatic Gain Control, measured in dB. Valid range, -50.0 to 50.0

  • cn0DbHz
    number
    format: float[ -100 .. 100 ]uid: cn0DbHz

    The Carrier-to-noise density in dB-Hz, which represents the measured C/N0 for the signal at the antenna inputCarrier to noise density ratio, measured in dB-Hz. Typical range: 10-50 dB-Hz. The range of possible C/N0 values is 0-63 dB-Hz to handle some edge cases.

  • hdop
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 50 ]uid: hdop

    Horizontal Dilution of Precision. Valid range, 0.0 to 50.0.

  • vdop
    number
    format: float[ 0 .. 50 ]uid: vdop

    Vertical Dilution of Precision. Valid range, 0.0 to 50.0.

  • frequencyHz
    integer
    format: int64>= 1uid: frequencyHz

    The frequency, in Hz, that the radio signal was received on.

  • bandwidthHz
    integer
    format: int32>= 1uid: bandwidthHz

    The bandwidth, in Hz, of the received signal.

  • snr
    number
    format: floatuid: snr

    The Signal to Noise Ratio of the received signal to the noise power measured in dB. A ratio higher than 1:1 (greater than 0 dB) indicates more signal than noise.

  • timeUp
    string
    format: date-timeuid: timeUp

    The date & time the energy/signal was detected as active. This is formatted as an RFC3339 date-time. For example, '1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00'.

  • durationSec
    number
    format: float> 0uid: durationSec

    The duration of time, in seconds, that the signal was detected as active.

  • modulation
    string
    uid: modulation

    The modulation type found on the received signal. It is appropriate to leave this blank if the modulation of the signal is unknown, but either the modulation or signalName field should be filled out. If neither of them are known then the energyDetection message should be used instead.

  • signalName
    string
    uid: signalName

    The modulation type found on the received signal. It is appropriate to leave this blank if the modulation of the signal is unknown, but either the modulation or signalName field should be filled out. If neither of them are known then the energyDetection message should be used instead.

  • batteryLevelPercent
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 100 ]uid: batteryLevelPercent

    The percentage of battery remaining (if the device has a battery).

  • object
    uid: error

    If present, represents that the device is in an error state.

    errorMessage
    required
    string

    A description of the error state that the device is in.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • mdmOverride
    boolean
    uid: mdmOverride

    Indicates if the device currently has the Mobile Device Mangement (MDM) Override option turned on. If true, the user has forced the MDM options off, if false, the user has left the MDM control in place. Added in version 0.9.0.

  • simState
    string
    uid: simState

    The current state of the SIM card. The values are taken directly from android.telephony.TelephonyManager#SimState and should be kept in sync with those values. Even the order lines up exactly, which makes conversion easier.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "ABSENT"
    • "PIN_REQUIRED"
    • "PUK_REQUIRED"
    • "NETWORK_LOCKED"
    • "READY"
    • "NOT_READY"
    • "PERM_DISABLED"
    • "CARD_IO_ERROR"
    • "CARD_RESTRICTED"
    • "LOADED"
    • "PRESENT"
  • simOperator
    string
    uid: simOperator

    The PLMN portion of the SIM's IMSI. This indicates the provider that issued the SIM card. The format is the MCC and MNC concatenated as one string. Can be 5 or 6 digits in length where the MCC is always 3 digits and the MNC is either 2 or 3.

  • object
    uid: networkRegistrationInfo

    A network that this device is registered to, or tried to register to.

    domain
    string

    The type of network, either Packet Switched (PS) or Circuit Switched (CS).

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "PS"
    • "CS"
    accessNetworkTechnology
    string

    The technology type for this network, for example, UMTS or LTE. These values mirror the Android TelephonyManager Network Type constants.

      Allowed values:
    • "UNKNOWN"
    • "GPRS"
    • "EDGE"
    • "UMTS"
    • "CDMA"
    • "EVDO_0"
    • "EVDO_A"
    • "OnexRTT"
    • "HSDPA"
    • "HSUPA"
    • "HSPA"
    • "IDEN"
    • "EVDO_B"
    • "LTE"
    • "EHRPD"
    • "HSPAP"
    • "GSM"
    • "TD_SCDMA"
    • "IWLAN"
    • "LTE_CA"
    • "NR"
    roaming
    boolean

    Boolean indicating if this device is roaming on this network.

    rejectCause
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    If the UE tried to register with this network and was denied, this vlaue indicates the rejection reason. The values are defined in 3GPP TS 24.008 version 16.7.0 page 536 (Reject cause), and 3GPP TS 24.301 version 16.8.0 page 418 (EMM cause).

    oneOf

    The properties defining the cell. The properties are different for each technology so the object type will be different depending on the accessNetworkTechnology. The name of this field will be different for each object. For example, it will be cellIdentityLte for LTE and cellIdentityNr for NR.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityGsm

    Contains the information about a particular GSM cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    lac
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: lac

    Location Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

    ci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: ci

    Cell Identity of the measured cell, valid range 0-65535.

    arfcn
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: arfcn

    Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid values defined in 3GPP TS 45.005 Release 10 Section 2.

    bsic
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 63 ]uid: bsic

    Base Station Identity Code, consists of NCC and BCC, valid range 0-63 (in octal). For example, a BSIC of 38 maps to an NCC of 4 and BCC of 6.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityCdma

    Contains the information about a particular CDMA cell.

    sid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 32767 ]uid: sid

    System Identification Number, 15 bit number that represents the service provider(s) a base station provides service to.

    nid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: nid

    Network Identification Number, 16 bit number that represents the network within a SID.

    bsid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: bsid

    Base Station Identifier. Exclusively identifies a base station under a SID/NID.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityUmts

    Contains the information about a particular UMTS cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    lac
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: lac

    Location Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

    cid
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 268435455 ]uid: cid

    The Cell Identity of the measured cell, 28 bits, the RNC-ID is the first 12 bits, and the C-ID is the last 16 bits, valid range 0-268435455. Defined in 3GPP TS 25.331.

    uarfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 13096 ]uid: uarfcn

    UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number (Downlink), valid range 0-13096, defined in 3GPP TS 25.101 and 3GPP TS 25.102.

    psc
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 511 ]uid: psc

    Primary Scrambling Code, valid range 0-511.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityLte

    Contains the information about a particular LTE cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mcc

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mnc

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    tac
    integer
    [ 0 .. 65535 ]uid: tac

    Tracking Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0-65535.

    eci
    integer
    [ 0 .. 268435455 ]uid: eci

    ECI, the Cell Identity of the measured cell, 28 bits. The Macro eNB ID is the first 20 bits of the Cell Identity and the last 8 bits represent the sector. Valid range 0-268435455.

    earfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 262143 ]uid: earfcn

    Downlink E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid range 0-262143, defined in 3GPP TS 36.331 version 14.2.2 Release 14 page 567.

    pci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 503 ]uid: pci

    Physical Cell Identity, valid range 0-503.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    object
    uid: cellIdentityNr

    Contains the information about a particular NR cell.

    mcc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mcc

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc
    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mnc

    Mobile Network Code, used in conjunction with MCC (PLMN) to identify a carrier, 2 to 3 digits.

    tac
    integer
    [ 0 .. 16777215 ]uid: nrTac

    NR Tracking Area Code, location code inside a PLMN, valid range 0 - 16,777,215 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 643.

    nci
    string
    format: int64[ 0 .. 68719476735 ]uid: nci

    NCI, the Cell Identity of the measured cell, 36 bits. The gNB ID is the first 22-32 bits of the NCI and the remaining bits represent the sector. Valid range 0 - 68,719,476,735 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 370.

    narfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 3279165 ]uid: narfcn

    Downlink NR Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid range 0 - 3,279,165, defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 784.

    pci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 1007 ]uid: nrPci

    NR Physical Cell Identity, valid range 0-1007 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 503.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    Additional properties are allowed.

    uid: cellIdentityGsm

    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: arfcn

    Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid values defined in 3GPP TS 45.005 Release 10 Section 2.

    bsic
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 63 ]uid: bsic

    uid: cellIdentityNr

    Contains the information about a particular NR cell.

    integer
    format: int32>= 0uid: mcc

    Mobile Country Code, 3 digits.

    mnc

    format: int32>= 0uid: mnc

    [ 0 .. 16777215 ]uid: nrTac

    nci
    string
    format: int64[ 0 .. 68719476735 ]uid: nci

    NCI, the Cell Identity of the measured cell, 36 bits. The gNB ID is the first 22-32 bits of the NCI and the remaining bits represent the sector. Valid range 0 - 68,719,476,735 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 370.

    narfcn
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 3279165 ]uid: narfcn

    Downlink NR Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number, valid range 0 - 3,279,165, defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 784.

    pci
    integer
    format: int32[ 0 .. 1007 ]uid: nrPci

    NR Physical Cell Identity, valid range 0-1007 as defined in 3GPP TS 38.331 version 16.2.0 Release 16 page 503.

    Additional properties are allowed.

  • pcapRecord
    string
    format: byteuid: pcapRecord

    The raw cellular message bytes encoded in base64. The bytes in this field are the raw message bytes captured from the Over The Air (OTA) cellular radio frame with the appropriate PCAP headers as the prefix. In other words, the bytes are the same bytes that would show up in a pcap file for a cellular message. The general structure consists of a PCAP record header, PPI header, layer 3 header, layer 4 header, a GSMTAP header, followed by the cellular OTA message. Using this structure means that Wireshark, tshark or any other tool that can read GSMTAP pcap records can easily parse out the contents of this message. For more details see the Network Survey+ Android App Source Code.

  • channelType
    string
    uid: channelType

    The channel type that this message was sent on. The channel type represents the logical channel that the raw cellular message was sent over.
